etymologies: mid 16th century; earliest use found in Thomas Cranmer (1489–1556), archbishop of Canterbury. From post-classical Latin delegatorius acting as a delegate, of or relating to delegation from delegator + classical Latin -ius, suffix forming adjectives

definitions: Of power, authority, etc.: that is of a delegated nature or type; (also) characterized by or involving delegation. Formerly also of a person: †holding delegated authority (obsolete).
